abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Technical Assistance
            Project for Mongolia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, project sustainability was likely, Bank
            performance was satisfactory and Borrower performance was
            also a satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            government commitment remains central to implementation
            success. The enthusiasm of the Government was a critical
            factor in meeting project objectives. However, when the
            respective agency did not consider the specific advisory
            service relevant to its perceived needs, implementation was
            less successful. Umbrella-type projects with their high
            degree of flexibility require careful assessment of the
            Borrower's capacity to implement. Involvement of many
            international agencies may make project, related budget
            plans too complicated. While reliance on agencies to make
            their own work plans may make the process demand-driven and
            participatory, it may not always be appropriate or relevant
            in fulfilling objectives of project.

docna.cdata!:
Mongolia - Technical Assistance Project :
            Credit 2321 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Mongolia - Technical Assistance
            Project : Credit 2321 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

18156012.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The Technical Assistance Project will
            help Mongolia develop its institutional capacity for
            macroeconomic management in a market economy. It will also
            help define strategies for sectors/subsectors key to
            Mongolia's economic development and, as appropriate,
            demonstrate or confirm the feasibility of selected public
            investments. The project has two components. The first, a
            program of advisory assistance, in-country and overseas
            training, and material support will concentrate on
            developing Mongolia's institutional capacity for
            macroeconomic management and reform. Assistance will be
            directed at the institutions with key roles to play in the
            transition. The second component will finance strategic
            studies in selected sectors/subsectors key to the long-term
            development of Mongolia's economy, and feasibility
            studies of key projects identified in light of these sector strategies.
